In [[computing]], the Red Hat '''Virtual Machine Manager''' is a desktop-driven virtual-machine manager application with which users can manage [[virtual machine]]s (VMs).<ref> {{cite book |first1= Ellen |last1= Siever |first2= Stephen |last2= Figgins |first3= Robert |last3= Love |first4= Arnold |last4= Robbins |author3-link= Robert Love |title=Linux in a Nutshell |edition= 6 |date= 2009-09-22 |publisher= O'Reilly |isbn= 978-0-596-15448-6 |page= 850 |pages= 944 |quote= [...] the Red Hat Virtual Machine Manager application [...] is a collection of tools built using libvirt. This includes a few command-line tools as well as the GUI virt-manager application. }} </ref>
== Features == Virtual Machine Manager allows users to:
* create, edit, start and stop VMs * view and control of each VM's console * see performance & utilization statistics for each VM * view all running VMs and hosts and their live performance & resource utilization statistics. * use [[Kernel-based Virtual Machine|KVM]], [[Xen]] or [[QEMU]] virtual machines, running either locally or remotely.
== Distributions including Virtual Machine Manager ==
Virtual Machine Manager comes as the 'virt-manager' package in:
* [[Arch Linux]] * [[Debian]] (since lenny) * [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] (since version 6) * [[Frugalware]] * [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]] * [[Mandriva Linux]] (since release 2007.1) * [[Opensuse]] (since release 10.3) * [[Red Hat Enterprise Linux]] 5 * [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] (version 8.04 and above) * [[Oracle Linux]]
== Documentation ==
Documentation exists both inside Virtual Machine Manager and at its [http://virt-manager.org/ website].
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 5 virtualization documentation comes in the form of the [http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/enterprise/RHEL-5-manual/Virtualization-en-US RHEL Virtualization Guide].
Ubuntu 8.04 virtualization documentation comes with the [http://doc.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/serverguide/C/virtualization.html Ubuntu Server Guide].
